oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "A Speck of Pepper in the Grits”: The Fugitive Lives of Black Women Teachers Staying in K-12
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Samuels, Shalander
Wilkerson , Amanda
Acquaye, Hannah
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fugitivity
Fugitive Pedagogy
Black women teachers
Freedom
Resistance
COVID-19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Since the Brown v. Board of Education decision, the plight of Black educators continues to be one of resilience and resistance. One important question to consider is how Black teachers continue to live out the mission of Brown while navigating the Covid-19 pandemic. Using Givens’ (2021) Fugitive pedagogy framework, this narrative inquiry explored Black Women teachers’ resistance as a mechanism to fulfill the promises of the Brown decision. We found that participants enacted the following forms of resistance: a) intellectual acts of subversion, b) fictive kinship, and c) resisting by enacting shared vulnerability. Findings shine light on the complexities of exhibiting resistance in anti-Black K-12 classroom settings. Furthermore, we discuss implications for K-12 administrators, teacher preparation programs, and education policymakers.
